Top 10 Hotels in Las Vegas: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
items.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate their favorite hotels in Las Vegas. [_View as a List_](http://www.cntraveler.com/readers-choice-awards/2014/united-states/best-hotels-in-las-vegas-readers-choice-awards-2014)
items.seoTitle: Top 10 Hotels in Las Vegas: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
items.seoDescription: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate their favorite hotels in Las Vegas.
items.socialDescription: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate their favorite hotels in Las Vegas.

items.title: [10. Delano Las Vegas (formerly THEhotel)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/thehotel-at-mandalay-bay--las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 81.200

The latest edition to the Strip opened its doors in fall 2014, taking its cues from the Delano in Miami Beach. The entrance is flanked by two massive boulders sourced from the surrounding desert; inside, the atmosphere is stylish and modern, artfully lit and dominated by earth tones. A pool is set to open in 2015, but in the meantime, guests can use the neighboring Mandalay Bay’s artificial beach, complete with wave pool. The Bathhouse Spa offers a variety of internationally inspired treatments. By night, guests can hang out at the swanky lobby bar, the Franklin.

items.title: [9. Aria](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/aria--las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 81.815

This mega-hotel at the CityCenter has all the fixings: more than 4,000 rooms in a Five Diamond hotel, 16 restaurants, three pools, and a spa where you can recline on Japanese stone beds. Aria has its own Cirque du Soleil show—the magic-themed *Zarkana*—plus four nightlife spots and 15 restaurants. A light-up fountain greets you at the entrance, followed by sculptor Maya Lin’s massive installation, *Silver River.*

items.title: [8. M Resort, Spa, Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/m-resort-spa-and-casino)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 82.101

Among the most architecturally sleek of the buildings on the Strip, the M’s wide-open, well-lit feel extends throughout. Both guest rooms and the gambling floor boast floor-to-ceiling windows, annihilating the detached-from-reality feel of most casinos. The 110,000-square-foot Villaggio Del Sole Pool and Entertainment Piazza is a spacious outdoor area featuring four pools and Jacuzzis. The M is also home to the Hostile Grape Wine Cellar, which pours 160 varieties of vino by the glass; a spa and fitness center; and seven restaurants.
items.credit: Courtesy M Resort, Spa and Casino

items.title: [7. The Venetian]
items.caption: Readers' Rating: 83.382

items.title: [7. The Venetian](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-venetian)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 83.382

The only place in Vegas (and possibly anywhere else) where you can take a gondola ride indoors, this resort-casino re-creates the City of Water in impressive detail. Shop-lined canals run through the hotel, with an artificial blue sky overhead. Pamper yourself at the Canyon Ranch SpaClub, which features everything from water therapy to a 40-foot-high climbing wall. There’s even a Madame Tussauds on-site, plus 20 restaurants shared with sister resort the Palazzo. Stay in the Venezia Tower, whose suites include Roman tubs and remote-controlled curtains.

items.title: [6. Four Seasons Hotel Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/four-seasons--las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.283

With five floors of rooms on top of the Mandalay Bay resort, this spot is smaller and more exclusive than your average Strip hotel—it *is* the Four Seasons, after all. This casino-free zone is far removed from the chaos below. Lounge waterside on a palm-tree-covered deck beside the 8,000-square-foot pool, and rest in throwback comfort in an Art Deco–inspired suite. The spa offers massages, facials and hot-stone treatments. Dine on Italian food at Veranda, or artisanal aged beef at Charlie Palmer Steak.
items.credit: Courtesy Four Seasons Hotel Las Vegas

items.title: [5. The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 84.536

*Traveler* readers have called this newish spot, open since 2010, “fresh, fun, [and] sophisticated, yet not too Vegas.” With a modern vibe and quirky amenities—like cigarette machines that have been repurposed to dispense art pieces—the Cosmopolitan provides a welcome respite from the theme-iness of other hotels on the Strip. High-end rooms feature wraparound private terraces with skyline views. And it’s all about the nightlife here: Among your options are a three-story bar built inside a giant chandelier, and a hybrid nightclub/interactive show called *Rose. Rabbit. Lie.*
items.credit: Courtesy The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas

items.title: [4. Bellagio](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/bellagio--las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.964

An eight-and-a-half-acre manmade lake dominates the grounds of this casino-resort, which erupts into a dazzling choreographed fountain display every 15 to 30 minutes. It’s the best free entertainment to be had on the Strip, but you have to go inside for the real glamour. The entryway is dominated by artist Dale Chihuly’s hand-blown glass sculpture, and the casino is home to a legendary high-stakes poker room. Take in Cirque du Soleil’s embedded show, *O,* and stay in the Five Diamond–winning comfort of the Bellagio’s Tuscan-style suites and villas.

items.title: [3. Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/mandarin-oriental--las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 85.965

Asian-style elegance is the order of the day at this resort, situated within the CityCenter complex, whose hotel, restaurant and spa are all five-starred. The Zen-like atmosphere here, high above the street, offers a serene escape from the hectic bustle of the Strip. A two-floor spa includes 17 treatment rooms, a Chinese foot spa and a pool deck. The rooms, decorated in a contemporary Eastern aesthetic, are tricked out with temperature- and tech-controlling touch screens. Sip a cocktail at the Mandarin Bar, which also serves tapas and 23-story views of the surrounding city.

items.title: [2. The Palazzo](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-palazzo)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 86.181

This sister hotel to the Venetian boasts more than 3,000 suites, complete with amenities like sunken living rooms and foyers made of Italian marble. Italian opulence is the vibe here, complete with a waterfall in the atrium and a five-acre roof deck dotted with Roman-style pools. Sample food at the resort’s 20 restaurants, helmed by the likes of Wolfgang Puck, Emeril Lagasse, Mario Batali and Daniel Boulud.
items.credit: Courtesy The Palazzo Resort and Casino

items.title: [1. Wynn Las Vegas and Encore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/wynn-and-encore-las-vegas)
items.caption:
Readers' Rating: 87.079

Casino-resort the Wynn and its offshoot, Encore, have a list of five-star awards (Michelin, Forbes, Mobil, AAA) as long as the Strip itself. From the Venetian-glass mosaic floors to white sycamore furnishings, everything about the hotel oozes luxury. Sit down for a bite at any of the 10 on-site fine dining restaurants, watch aquatic acrobatic spectacle *Le Rêve,* and then retire to an upscale suite in the Tower or the Resort. And that’s only scratching the pearl-inlaid marble surface.
items.credit: Courtesy Wynn Las Vegas & Encore Resort

fields.name: Jenna Scherer
fields.shortBio: Jenna is a Brooklyn-based writer, editor, and rouser of rabble.
fields.bio: Jenna is a writer, editor, and pop-culture critic whose work has appeared in *Rolling Stone, Hemispheres Magazine,* Made Man, *The Boston Herald,* Time Out Boston, and The Watershed Post. Most recently, she was associate editor at *Time Out New York.* Journalistic research has taken her from the catwalks of haunted theaters in Boston to helicopters over Manhattan. When traveling, she can usually be found climbing to the tops of very tall things. She lives in Brooklyn.

fields.title: [Viceroy Riviera Maya](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/mexico/the-tides-riviera-maya-riviera-maya-mexico)

items.hed: The 2015 Friendliest and Unfriendliest Cities in the World
items.dek: For the third year running, we've asked our readers to rate a city's "friendliness" in the [Readers’ Choice Awards survey](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-awards/readers-choice-awards/2014). We found out [which U.S. cities greet visitors with open arms](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-08-11/the-2015-friendliest-and-unfriendliest-cities-in-the-us); now read on for which international cities were warm (or had a chill in the air).

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 10. Reykjavik, Iceland
items.caption: "Like nowhere else in Europe," this world's most northerly capital city is "an eye-opening experience as to the Icelanders' ability to make the most of an inhospitable climate" with their "deep sense of culture, intellect, sophistication, and friendliness." "The hospitality was amazing, no matter who you met." Plus: "Reykjavik is hip, and the locals like to party!"

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 9. Auckland, New Zealand
items.caption: Auckland's "unbelievably friendly folk" were found to be some of the most "polite and accommodating" in the world. One reader was "invited by strangers to the Chinese Lantern Festival on a hill overlooking the city"; another local recommended taking "the ferry to the north shore Devonport suburb for the perfect combination of funky and shabby chic." Overall, most agreed that there were "absolutely wonderful people everywhere!" Tied for Friendliest City in 2014.

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 8. Budapest, Hungary
items.caption: Budapest is a "beautiful city with a history that makes you smile and cry," and "friendly people anxious to show everyone everything" with "a wonderful sense of humor, in spite of their difficult history." "We loved mixing with the locals in the many hot springs baths," and more than one reader mentioned "music wherever we went... not just concerts, but in the streets, on the radio, and in cafés." "Stay on the Pest side, explore the Buda side" and "if you have kids, go to the entertaining Szabó Marzipan Museum." Up from no. 10 Friendliest in 2014.

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 7. Kyoto, Japan
items.caption: Despite many a misconception, "the Japanese are extremely friendly. The best way to get to know them is to visit the same places more than once," or "invite them to lunch or dinner and you'll discover things you would never have known about." "Every step in Kyoto is filled with memorable sights," with one couple remembering finding "a little restaurant while walking around Gion. It was well off the beaten path and had no menu in English or English-speaking staff, but we had an incredible meal and a fabulous time." Best put: "Peace can be found among others. Such beauty and care for the city. The temples are for all to enjoy and meditate and marvel at."

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 6. Edinburgh, Scotland
items.caption: "People really went out of their way to help us, direct us, and serve us," recalled recent visitors. There were "wonderful pubs filled with laughter," and "local musicians playing and everyone smiling and singing along." "What a hoot!" "Visiting Edinburgh Castle with a private guide was terrific. We learned all about the salacious side of Scottish history," plus, "seeing the city lit up by fireworks on New Year's Eve was an extraordinary treat" surrounded by "cheerful and lovely crowds." Beware though: The only chill comes from the weather. "Always pack a warm coat," even in August, said one reader.

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 5. Bruges, Belgium
items.caption: "Being in Bruges is like being in a fairy tale. Literally every time I turned a corner I expected Prince Charming to show up because I felt like Cinderella at the ball." The city is "quaint, bustling, teeming with people, sights, and sounds"; many noted that it was most "peaceful in the early morning and late evening once tour groups had left"—the perfect time to "take a carriage tour along the canals with a friendly carriage master telling stories of the history and locals." "Friendly shopkeepers" and no dearth of "cafés serving warm waffles with chocolate sauce" equalled "exactly what we imagined an old European city should be like."

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 4. Kraków, Poland
items.caption: "What a surprise and a treasure Kraków is!" "Still known more to Europeans than Americans, it's a gem" with some of the "friendliest locals you'll ever meet." They certainly have a good sense of humor: A "don't-miss adventure is to take a light-hearted Communism Tour with [Crazy Guides](http://www.crazyguides.com/)" in a vintage Trabant car through the centrally planned Socialist district of Nowa Huta. Another spirited trip is to "climb the stairs to the top of Wawel Castle's tower and touch the Sigismund Bell for good luck"—your right hand for love, your left for wealth, but never both!

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 3. Queenstown, New Zealand
items.caption: This South Island city is "the birthplace of adventure tourism—50 ways to kill yourself every day!" said one reader. It's also "loads of fun and has great people-watching." "Very friendly locals genuinely enjoy interacting with tourists," including "a helicopter pilot who landed us in six different places on our tour... including a glacier and his favorite 'lunch spot,' which couldn't have been bigger than a picnic blanket." With "so much to do," and "a great bar scene at night," "you can't NOT have a good time in Queenstown." It's "a bucket list city, but you'll need a bucket of money" to visit, warned one reader.

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 2. Dublin, Ireland
items.caption: "The people make the place" here, with "pubs and restaurants filled with locals and tourists alike, coming together to celebrate life." ("I've never been somewhere with friendlier drinkers.") "The Irish are so much fun," and "there's always a smiling face to talk to." Top tips: "Best hidden gem is Marsh's Library, smaller than the one at Trinity but more accessible," and "ditch the crowded tour at Guinness and go directly to the bar at the top." The city seems to have become "the 'new' Barcelona, without the sunstroke." Up from no. 5 Friendliest in 2014.

items.title: __FRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 1. Sydney, Australia
items.caption: "*Such* friendly people," enthused one reader, "so much so that after we met an Australian woman on our flight there, she offered to pick us up at our hotel and spent a whole day showing us her favorite parts of the city." Another reader loved the ['Cruise Like a Local'](http://www.seasydneycruises.com.au/) small group Sydney Harbour boat tour "with a fantastic BBQ lunch, swimming, and fishing like I was on my own private yacht." "[Bonza Bike Tours](http://www.bonzabiketours.com/sydney/home.php) are a great way to see some of the lesser-known sights," though many proclaimed: "You haven't seen the place properly if you haven't done the famous bridge climb." All in all, there's simply "nothing to not like." Tied for no. 5 Friendliest in 2014.

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 10. Cannes, France
items.caption: "Bloated simply by the prestige of its famed film festival," the city is home to "lots of lovely yachts and fancy hotels" but it's also filled with "very wealthy, thin, snobby people" whom many deemed more than "a tad rude." Undeniably "cosmopolitan," if "too much glitz" overwhelms "get out of town to find secret, quiet places nearby." Visitors beware: "Ask for prices if they aren't listed on menus. We ordered a two-pound lobster, which we shared, and the bill was €240. It must have been made of solid gold!" No. 2 Unfriendliest in 2014.

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 9. Jakarta, Indonesia
items.caption: Besides being "dirty and congested," one traveler found it "the scariest place I've ever been to," with "aggressive locals." The city seems to be teeming: "It took us two hours to get from the airport to our hotel because of bumper-to-bumper traffic." "In addition, the rainy season [October through May] wreaks havoc due to excessive and uncontrolled flooding." That said, travelers should "try the Padang food stalls." They might intimidate at first, "but the meals are incredible."

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 8. Moscow, Russia
items.caption: "Dour, unfriendly people," "deplorable traffic," and "no philosophy of pleasing the visitor" didn't help Moscow. Plus the city "is HUGE and in Cyrillic" with "few signs or menus in English" ("store clerks weren't helpful, probably because of the language barrier"). The "Red Square and the Kremlin are incredible," as are the "elegant subway stations," but for the most part it's a city visited best for "an interesting historical education." No. 3 Unfriendliest in 2014.

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 7. Cairo, Egypt
items.caption: "Cairo was a dream getaway for us, but it turned into more of a nightmare," and the "pyramids were only memorable for how disappointing they were." "Horrible traffic and trash everywhere," "pushy vendors and beggars," "greedy guides," and "locals offering suspicious assistance" meant that despite "the vast sense of human history" and "stunning artifacts at the Egyptian Museum," this is "a pretty scary city."

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 6. New Delhi, India
items.caption: "Depressing and filthy," said more than a few. "It took me three weeks to recover," exclaimed one reader, echoing others who mentioned "extremely poor air quality"—so bad "friends had to leave because doctors told them to go home." "Drivers were rude" in "monster traffic jams"; and "safety is a concern if you're not with the right people or in a tour group." Beware the "blistering heat in summer." It's an "eye-opening experience with everything in the streets, including trash, cows, monkeys, etc.," enough so that "once is sufficient."
items.credit: Sanjeev Verma/Hindustan Times via Getty Images

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 5. Nairobi, Kenya
items.caption: "Dangerous and volatile, Nairobi doesn't feel like a safe place to get around; on my morning runs I was escorted by hotel police in a Jeep." Kenya's "crowded and smoggy" capital is a "true quagmire," with "possibly the worst airport ever." "Best for buying African crafts," visiting the "relaxing oasis of the Karen Blixen Museum and Giraffe Centre in the suburbs," or as a quick "stopover en route to a safari."

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 4. Guatemala City, Guatemala
items.caption: "Dirty and unfriendly," this Central American city "isn't a good place for tourists. Even the Guatemalans are worried about the crime rate" with "violence in broad daylight." A necessary stop if on your way to beautiful Antigua or Lake Atitlán, "you can trust locals to tell you that the steak *parillas* in San Lucas are the best in the city and worth the traffic," and "the Christmas spirit here is unmatched." It still seems "too dangerous" for most, though.

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 3. Guangzhou, China
items.caption: "Crowded, dirty, and polluted" was how one reader summed up China's third-largest city, located on the Pearl River. Formerly known as Canton, there are a "handful of interesting sites to visit, like the Temple of the Six Banyan Trees," but "lots of spitting! Yuck!" "So close to Hong Kong," under two hours by train, "yet so far," it has grown into a major industrial center and trade hub "for everything and anything the country produces." On the plus side, "the local cuisine is amazing."

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 2. Casablanca, Morocco
items.caption: "Not what the movie suggested. Time has not served this dirty city well," opined one visitor. Morocco's largest metropolis is "chock full of overwhelming sensory experiences," "pestering street vendors and merchants," "traffic jams, screaming people," and "intense extremes." Put it this way: "The Hassan II Mosque was unbelievably beautiful, but three blocks away there was nothing but poverty."

items.title: __UNFRIENDLIEST CITIES:__ 1. Caracas, Venezuela
items.caption: "Caracas used to be a great place, friendly and cosmopolitan, but in the last decade it's taken a turn for the worse with rampant crime, a scarcity of basic necessities, and a poor quality of life," said one reader. "Not the place to get a morning run or walk in"; even "the candy bars were under lock and key in the grocery store!" "Hopefully it will improve, but for now it's no destination for anyone looking for an open-armed welcome."

items.seoTitle: The 2015 Friendliest (and Unfriendliest) Cities in the World
items.seoDescription: For the third year running, we've asked our readers to rate a city's "friendliness" in the Readers’ Choice Awards survey. We already announced the U.S. cities that greet visitors with open arms; now read on for which international cities were warm (or had a chill in the air).
items.socialTitle: The 10 Friendliest (and Unfriendliest) Cities in the World
items.socialDescription: For the third year running, we've asked our readers to rate a city's "friendliness" in the Readers’ Choice Awards survey. We already announced the U.S. cities that greet visitors with open arms; now read on for which international cities were warm (or had a chill in the air).

items.hed: The 30 Best Small Cities in America: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
items.dek: Here are the small American charmers, as voted on by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers. All have populations of under 100,000, and often as much to offer as cities ten times their size.

items.title: #30. Newport Beach, CA
items.caption: Check out the legendary waves at beautiful Balboa Peninsula, where surfers reign and a nearby bustling boardwalk offers some of the best people-watching in all of sunny SoCal. Stay at [The Resort at Pelican Hill](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/newport-coast/resort-at-pelican-hill--newport-coast), in an elegant, Palladian-inspired villa overlooking the Pacific.

items.title: #29. Annapolis, MD
items.caption: History buffs, take note: Maryland's capital city is home to the U.S. Naval Academy (and its bright copper-domed chapel, pictured) and more than 50 well-preserved buildings that predate the Revolutionary War. Stop in for crab cakes at the Middleton Tavern, which dates to 1750 and counts  George Washington, Benjamin Franklin, and Thomas Jefferson as former famous patrons, among others.

items.title: #28. Palm Springs, CA
items.caption: Soak up old Hollywood glamour mixed with breathtaking scenery in this ultra-hip desert oasis. Stay at the candy-colored [Saguaro Palm Springs](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-springs/the-saguaro--palm-springs) (pictured) and dine at Copley's on Palm Canyon, once Cary Grant's estate.

items.title: #27. Palm Beach, FL
items.caption: The city is home to the largest croquet complex in the world, but it’s the beachfront mega-mansions most visitors make sure to check out, either with a bike ride or a cruise on the Palm Beach Water Taxi. For the ultimate South Florida experience, stay at [The Breakers](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-beach/the-breakers--palm-beach), listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

items.title: #26. Eureka Springs, AR
items.caption: In the middle of the Ozark Mountains, Eureka Springs is full of Victorian charm, and is affectionately known as 'The Little Switzerland of America.' Get in the mindset with a stay at The 1886 Crescent Hotel and Spa, whose velvet couches and crystal-filled ballroom will transport you back to the 19th century; but be on the lookout for ghosts (some claim this is the most haunted hotel in the country).

items.title: #25. Hilo, HI
items.caption: It's no secret that Hawaii is full of beautiful scenery. Hilo is home to dramatic waterfalls and sunsets, as well as the Pana'ewa Rainforest Zoo, the only U.S. zoo in a tropical rainforest. Spend the night at the charming, Victorian-era Shipman House Bed & Breakfast in the center of town.

items.title: #24. Ashland, OR
items.caption: At the base of the Siskiyou and Cascade mountain ranges, the scenery here is second to none—and the town’s year-round mild weather doesn’t disappoint, either. Despite being thousands of miles from England, the Oregon Shakespeare Festival draws major crowds, and the [Ashland Springs Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/ashland/ashland-springs-hotel) has a distinctively European flair in its 70 rooms.

items.title: #23. Healdsburg, CA
items.caption: You don’t need to be a lover of wine to relish the lush beauty and tranquility of this northern Sonoma County hamlet, just an hour’s drive from San Francisco. Farm-fresh food at many local restaurants earned Healdsburg the no. 8 spot on *Condé Nast Traveler's* Readers' Choice [list of America's best food cities](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-04-13/america-best-food-cities-readers-choice-awards-2014/13) and rooms at the [Madrona Manor](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/healdsburg/madrona-manor) are unapologetically romantic.

items.title: #22. Natchez, MS
items.caption: History runs deep in this historic Southern city, the oldest settlement on the Mississippi River. Many of the town's antebellum homes are open for public tours; be sure to book a room at the [Monmouth Historic Inn](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/natchez/monmouth-plantation--natchez), surrounded by 26 acres of beautifully maintained gardens.

items.title: #21. Monterey, CA
items.caption: Take advantage of one of the most scenic drives in the world, along 17-miles from Pacific Grove to Pebble Beach, featuring jaw-dropping vistas and legendary natural treasures including The Lone Cypress and Stillwater Cove. Steer clear of the happening (but touristy) scene at Cannery Row and instead head for [Restaurant 1833](http://www.restaurant1833.com/). Once the city’s first pharmacy, the spot is now known for its James Beard-nominated cuisine and silver-spoon absinthe service.

items.title: #20. Naples, FL
items.caption: Among the country’s best destinations for golf and sunshine, Naples is dotted with sleek hotels, top-notch shops, and restaurants. Two of our readers' favorite places to stay are the [Ritz-Carlton](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/ritz-carlton--naples) (pictured) and [LaPlaya Beach and Golf Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/laplaya-beach---golf-resort--naples).

items.title: #19. Portland, ME
items.caption: It might be the country’s smaller and lesser-known Portland, but this New England seaside town has made its mark as [a prime destination for foodies](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-02-05/restaurant-guide-portland-maine-eventide-oyster-co), whether you're in the mood for fresh oysters and a brown butter lobster roll at Eventide Oyster Co. or vegan treats from The Holy Donut. Opened in early 2015, [The Press Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-03-02/hotel-report-london-goring-hotel-reopens-portland-maine-newest-property) is housed in a former newspaper building, hence the name.

items.title: #18. Key West, FL
items.caption: The southernmost city in the continental U.S. is the ultimate place to kick back and soak up gorgeous year-round weather and worry-free energy from its bohemian collection of locals (and free-roaming chickens). Rooms at the Greek Revival-style [Marquesa Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/key-w/marquesa-hotel--key-west), built in 1884, are elegant and cheerfully-decorated (note: guests 14 and older only).

items.title: #17. St. Augustine, FL
items.caption: Founded by Spanish settlers in 1565, St. Augustine retains a rich historic charm along its cobblestone streets that make up the city's 144-block National Historic Landmark District. The eminent [Casa Monica Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/st-augustine/casa-monica-hotel--st--augustine), built in 1888, includes a luxury spa, the Spanish Mediterranean–inspired Costa Brava restaurant, and art gallery.

items.title: #16. Newport, RI
items.caption: There’s something for everyone in this [quintessential New England destination](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-05-06/what-to-do-in-newport-this-summer-volvo-ocean-race-historic-mansions-and-more) thanks to its historic mansions, excellent restaurants, and stunning seaside scenery. Tour one, or many, of the fabled "summer cottages" of America's Gilded Age and treat yourself to an opulently decorated room or villa at our readers' favorite: [The Chanler at Cliff Walk](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/newport/chanler-at-cliff-walk--newport).

items.title: #15. Santa Barbara, CA
items.caption: When the Hollywood elite need to retreat, they head to Santa Barbara. A visit to the Santa Barbara Mission, a stroll through the botanical gardens, and a stop at the town's Saturday morning farmer’s markets should all be on your to-do list—as is relaxing by the pool at the highly rated [Four Seasons Resort The Biltmore](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/santa-barbara/four-seasons-resort-the-biltmore--santa-barbara).

items.title: #14. Jackson, WY
items.caption: A mountain-lover's dream, Jackson (not to be confused with the Jackson Hole ski resort, 40 minutes north) still retains an original air of the "real" Wild West—don't forget to pack your cowboy boots, and be sure to book a room at the historic [Wort Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/jackson/the-wort-hotel), within walking distance of restaurants, bars, shops, and art galleries. It's Aspen, sans-Carey.

items.title: #13. Laguna Beach, CA
items.caption: There are plenty of pristine beaches in this Orange County treasure, but the most secluded and beautiful is Thousand Steps. Visitors descend a steep set of 218 stairs before being rewarded with postcard-worthy vistas and perfect waves. Stay at the peaceful [Surf & Sand Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/laguna-beach/surf---sand-resort--laguna-beach), a lavish hideaway with suites within earshot of the ocean.

items.title: #12. Burlington, VT
items.caption: Vermont is known for its shades-of-green scenery, and this bustling, bohemian, lakeside New England town is one of the best places to view it—any time of year. A rustic farm-to-table gastropub, The Farmhouse Tap and Grill features locally sourced ingredients and a wide selection of craft beers. Visitors and locals alike can’t seem to get enough and readers took to the quirky, contemporary [Hotel Vermont](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/burlington/hotel-vermont) as soon as it opened its doors in 2013.

items.title: #11. Cape May, NJ
items.caption: Cape May's quiet beaches, low-key locals, and gorgeous Victorian architecture exist in stark contrast to the Jersey Shore portrayed on reality television. Walk up the 199 steps at Cape May Point State Park for unparalleled hiking and panoramic views, then tuck in for the night at [The Virginia Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/cape-may/virginia-hotel--cape-may).

items.title: #10. Santa Rosa Beach, FL
items.caption: This idyllic town along the Florida panhandle has some of the clearest blue and emerald waters you’ve ever seen. Relaxing on a lounge chair at the [WaterColor Inn & Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/santa-rosa-beach/watercolor-inn---resort--santa-rosa-beach) (pictured) might be more than enough to occupy any day here, but there’s plenty of boating, kayaking, biking, shopping, and good bites for anyone active. Route 30A, a scenic stretch of highway that connects 15 beaches, is lined with a slew of great restaurants, like La Cocina for their stellar lobster quesadillas.

items.title: #9. Sarasota, FL
items.caption:
South of Tampa, and featuring some of the best beaches in the country, Sarasota is also home to an unexpected range of renowned art galleries.
The [Ritz-Carlton](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/sarasota/ritz-carlton--sarasota) is the ideal place to hang your hat. Service is indulgent and impeccable and the resort even has its own private beach club on nearby Lido Key and 18-hole championship golf course.

items.title: #8. Aspen, CO
items.caption: Renowned for its downhill skiing, the miniature year-round population of Aspen swells from 7,000 to 30,000 during winter. That said, it rarely feels crowded, but book well in advance for a room at the swanky [St. Regis Aspen](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/aspen/st-regis-aspen-resort-aspen-colorado), and a table at Matsuhisa for the freshest Japanese seafood to be had and about as far from the ocean as you can get (we recommend the rock shrimp tempura with butter ponzu).

items.title: #7. Park City, UT
items.caption: Spectacular alpine scenery and premium skiing might top the list of reasons to visit Park City, but the entertainment (like the Sundance Film Festival every winter), hiking, biking, and water sports are just as terrific. Bottom line? You’ll never be bored. Snag a suite with stone fireplace at the legendary [Stein Eriksen Lodge](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/ogden/stein-eriksen-lodge--park-city) in nearby Deer Valley and chow down at Butcher's Chop House & Bar on down-home classics like shrimp and grits, crab cakes, and beef short ribs.

items.title: #6. Sedona, AZ
items.caption: The scenery in Sedona—vast red rocks, expansive plateaus, steep canyons, and snow-capped mountains—is unlike anywhere else. Hiking Cathedral Rock affords some spectacular photo ops, while a drive along the Red Rock Scenic Byway takes you through the towering evergreens of the Coconino National Forest. [L’Auberge Sedona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/happy-jack/l-auberge-de-sedona--sedona) is a sublime French country-style inn set along the banks of Oak Creek.

items.title: #5. Napa, CA
items.caption: This legendary northern California town is no. 1 for bucket-list oenophiles, home to more than 400 local wineries. For an unusual take on the area hop a ride on the Napa Valley wine train, a 36-mile, three-hour journey in vintage carriages with optimal views, not to mention a multi-course dinner and private tours of two vineyards. Just south of of Napa, [The Carneros Inn](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/napa/carneros-inn--napa-valley) is surrounded by bountiful groves, fields, and orchards.

items.title: #4. Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
items.caption: Romance and relaxation are the order of the day in this exquisite California town. While it's a perfect getaway for lovebirds, you’ll also find plenty of top shopping and family-friendly amusements. Garlands Ranch Regional Park is a hidden gem for long, easy walks in pretty eucalyptus and sycamore-dotted flats. For overnights, the [Bernardus Lodge and Winery](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/carmel-valley/bernardus-lodge--carmel-valley) in nearby Carmel Valley has eight acres of its own vineyards and more than 300 rose bushes to stop and smell the good life.

items.title: #3. Asheville, NC
items.caption: Known for its Blue Ridge Mountain scenery and music scene, Asheville has also become a craft beer-brewing epicenter, with a lengthy list of local options and more breweries per capita than any other U.S. city. History buffs explore the 250-room, 8,000-acre Biltmore Estate, the largest privately owned home in the United States, built by George Vanderbilt in 1889. [The Grand Bohemian Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/asheville/grand-bohemian-hotel-asheville) is a favorite, and for good reason, with over-the-top, opulent accommodations.

items.title: #2. Santa Fe, NM
items.caption: World-renowned art museums and a thriving Native American culture are just two reasons to visit this historic city (home to the nation's oldest church—the San Miguel Mission, built between 1610 and 1626). [La Posada de Santa Fe Resort and Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/santa-fe/la-posada-de-santa-fe-resort---spa) has casita-style accommodations decked in expertly curated Southwestern artwork. Fuego, the onsite restaurant, serves local New American fare and its ambiance—fireplaces, chandeliers, dark-wood-beamed ceilings—is second to none.

items.title: #1. Telluride, CO
items.caption: Snow bunnies seeking adventure mixed with relaxation and luxury will be far from disappointed in this picturesque former Colorado mining town now known for its first-rate alpine skiing. Come summer, be sure to take in the hopping Bluegrass Festival, with live performances set against a stunning mountain backdrop. A penthouse suite with private, outdoor Jacuzzi at the [Lumière Telluride](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/telluride/lumiere-telluride) is a top contender for "best view," though some say dinner at Allred's Restaurant, 10,551 feet above town at the gondola terminus, can't be beat.

items.seoTitle: The 30 Best Small Cities in America: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
items.seoDescription: Here are the small American charmers, as voted on by Condé Nast Traveler readers. All have populations of under 100,000, and often as much to offer as cities ten times their size.
items.socialTitle: The 30 Best Small Cities in America
items.socialDescription: Here are the small American charmers, as voted on by Condé Nast Traveler readers. All have populations of under 100,000, and often as much to offer as cities ten times their size.

fields.name: Debbie Strong
fields.shortBio: Debbie Strong is a Boston-based freelance editor and writer, covering health, nutrition, and travel.
fields.bio: She has written for EverydayHealth.com, iVillage.com, Woman’s Day, Shape, Northshore, and several luxury travel publications, one of which gave her the tough assignment of reviewing spa treatments around the globe (all in the name of investigative reporting, of course). She’s also a barre fitness instructor and mom of one.

items.hed: The Trip Everyone In Their 20s Should Take
items.dek: Travel is for everyone, regardless of age, but the 2014 Readers' Choice Awards revealed an amazing trend: By the numbers, there was a memorable trip for every decade—the kind of journey you should really take in your twenties rather than your thirties. __Can you guess what experience each group, from Millennials to Sexagenarians, loved best, with the following clues?__

items.title: Our twentysomething readers wanted action.
items.caption:
It's all about swimming, snorkeling, diving, trekking, riding, and climbing for Millennials. From beaches to jungles, they’ve never been less afraid to hit the tropics with gusto.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: And they'll sleep anywhere—at a resort, or in a treehouse.
items.caption:
Bedtime options for the young and spritely ran from over-the-top, newly opened resorts to tents in the mountains, and bare-as-bones shacks by the seaside.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: They actually never slept—and reaped the benefit.
items.caption:
For most, a wake-up-call at 4 a.m. would be troublesome, but for those predisposed to adjust, it proved well worth their while to rise and shine to see some of this area’s most spectacular sights at dawn (well before anyone else) did.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: They didn't mind trading comfort for cost.
items.caption:
Cyclos, tuk-tuks, and auto rickshaws rattled their bones, but Millennials told us they cut through traffic better—and at a fraction of the cost of taxis and the dangerous thrill of hopping on motorbikes.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: They preferred to eat like a local...
items.caption:
Trust the young to find never-ending sources of scrumptious, cheap food quickly and easily (even if some of the ingredients seemed a tad questionable). Our youthful audience found their best meals wherever they saw the most locals dining.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: ...but shop for tourist trinkets.
items.caption:
Straw hats and shadow puppets, cotton sarongs and silk dresses: Finding amazing things to bring home was the least of any twentysomething’s worries here. Everything was affordable and packable (even in a rucksack).

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: They wanted to take a selfie with the elephant, not ride it.
items.caption:
There’s one thing important here, and anyone just out of school knows it. Our next generation of travelers are more in tune with what’s what in the world and would rather learn to feed an elephant than hop on top.

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: The trip's motto? "Sabaidi!"
items.caption:
New to the world of travel, our youngest respondents took to appreciating anything/everything local and genuine (including new languages).

*Where did 20-year-olds go? Keep clicking to find out.*

items.title: Where did they go? Southeast Asia (naturally).
items.caption:
First-time travelers in their twenties still backpack through Southeast Asia—from Thailand's Golden Triangle to the top-rated island in the world, [Palawan in the Philippines.](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-30-islands-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/30) They told us: It’s worth it.

Want to guess again? See if you know [The Trip Everyone In Their 30s Should Take.](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-01-12/the-trip-everyone-in-their-30s-should-take)

__Featured photos:__

#1. Railay Bay, Thailand
#2. [The Mulia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/indonesia/benoa/the-mulia--bali), Bali, Indonesia
#3. Cyclo in Vietnam
#4. Pho Binh Noodles, Vietnam
#5. Floating Market, Bangkok, Thailand
#6. Asian Elephants, Thailand
#7. Angkor Wat, Cambodia
#8. Kids in Luang Prabang, Laos
#9. Palawan, Philippines
